The binomial series

The binomial series is a more general form of the binomial theorem, that is, the expansion of \((x+1)^n\). When \(n\) is a natural number then we can expand \((x+1)^n\) using the usual laws of algebra and get a finite sum of terms. If \(n\) is not a natural number then the binomial theorem does not apply but we can get a series expansion. It is important to note that the series typically won't converge for all \(x\).

A very important infinite series which occurs often in applications and in algebra has the form:
\[
1+p x+\dfrac{p(p-1)}{2!}x^2+\dfrac{p(p-1)(p-2)}{3!}x^3+\cdots
\]
in which \(p\) is a given number and \(x\) is a variable. By using the ratio test it can be shown that this series converges, irrespective of the value of \(p\), as long as \(|x|<1\). In fact, as we shall see in Maclaurin and Taylor series that the given series converges to the value \((1+x)^p\) as long as \(|x|<1\).

Key Point

The Binomial Series

\[ (1+x)^p = 1+px+\frac{p(p-1)}{2!}x^2+\frac{p(p-1)(p-2)}{3!}x^3+\cdots \qquad |x|<1 \]

The binomial theorem can be obtained directly from the binomial series if \(p\) is chosen to be a positive integer (here we need not demand that \(|x|<1\) as the series is now finite and so is always convergent irrespective of the value of \(x\)). For example, with \(p=2\) we obtain
\[
\begin{aligned}
(1+x)^2&=& 1+2x+\dfrac{2(1)}{2}x^2+0+0+\cdots\\ &=&1+2x+x^2\ \ \ \text{as is well known.}
\end{aligned}
\]

With \(p=3\) we get
\[
\begin{aligned} (1+x)^3&=& 1+3x+\dfrac{3(2)}{2}x^2+\dfrac{3(2)(1)}{3!}x^3+0+0+\cdots &=&1+3x+3x^2+x^3
\end{aligned}
\]
Generally if \(p=n\) (a positive integer) then

\[ (1+x)^n=1+nx+\dfrac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2+\dfrac{n(n-1)(n-2)}{3!}x^3+\cdots +x^n \]

which is a form of the binomial theorem. If \(x\) is replaced by \(\dfrac{b}{a}\) then
\[
\left(1+\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n=1+n\left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)+\dfrac{n(n-1)}{2!}\left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^2+\cdots +\left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)^n
\]
Now multiplying both sides by \(a^n\) we have the following Key Point:

A generalisation of the third law of indices states:

Key Point

If \(n\) is a positive integer then the expansion of \( (a+b) \) raised to the power \(n\) is given by:

\[ (a+b)^n=a^n+na^{n−1}b+\frac{n(n−1)}{2!}a^{n−2}b^2+ \cdots +b^n.\]

This is known as the binomial theorem.
